ğŸŒŸ AAAI 2020

Abstract

tracking = classification task + estimation task

estimation task: (3 categories)

  1. ä»¥DCFã€SiamFCä¸ºä¸»çš„è¿½è¸ªå™¨ï¼Œåœ¨åŸå›¾ä¸Šä»¥å¤šå°ºåº¦ä¸ºåˆ’åˆ†ï¼Œå°†æœç´¢åŒºåŸŸç¼©æ”¾å¤šä¸ªæ¯”ä¾‹è¿›è¡Œç»„è£…ï¼Œå¹¶é€‰æ‹©æœ€é«˜åˆ†ç±»å¾—åˆ†å¯¹åº”çš„é‡è¡¨ (å¤šå°ºåº¦æµ‹è¯•)ï¼›ç›®æ ‡åœ¨ç›¸é‚»ä¸¤å¸§ä¸Šå°ºåº¦/é•¿å®½æ¯”ä»¥å›ºå®šé€Ÿç‡å˜åŒ–çš„å‡è®¾é€šå¸¸åœ¨ç°å®ä¸–ç•Œä¸æˆç«‹ã€‚

  2. ä»¥ATOMä¸ºä¸»çš„è¿½è¸ªå™¨ï¼Œå—åˆ°IOU-NETçš„å¯å‘ï¼Œä»¥è¿­ä»£è®­ç»ƒçš„æ–¹å¼å¤šé‡éšæœºåˆå§‹åŒ–å¸§ä¸èƒŒé¢è¾¹æ¡†çš„æ•°é‡ï¼Œè™½ç„¶æé«˜äº†ç²¾åº¦ï¼Œä½†å¸¦æ¥äº†è¾ƒå¤šçš„è¶…å‚æ•°ä»¥åŠæ—¶é—´ä¸Šçš„æ¶ˆè€—ï¼›

  3. ä»¥SiamRPNä¸ºä¸»çš„è¿½è¸ªå™¨ï¼Œä»¥RPNå›å½’çš„æ€æƒ³ï¼Œé¢„å…ˆå®šä¹‰é”šç‚¹ä¹‹é—´çš„ä½ç§»åç§»ä¸å¤§å°çš„å·®å¼‚ï¼Œæ­¤ç±»æ–¹æ³•åŸºäºç›®æ ‡æ£€æµ‹ï¼Œè™½ç„¶èƒ½å¤Ÿæ‰¾åˆ°ä¼˜ç§€çš„ç²¾ç¡®çš„çŠ¶æ€å€¼ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯å¯¹äºè¾ƒå¤§çš„å°ºåº¦å˜åŒ–ç­‰å›°éš¾æ ·ä¾‹æ¥è¯´ï¼Œé”šç‚¹ä¸æ¡†çš„å…ˆéªŒå› ç´ é™åˆ¶äº†è¿½è¸ªå™¨çš„é²æ£’æ€§ï¼Œå®¹æ˜“äº§ç”Ÿlostã€‚

75.4 AUC score, over 90 FPS on TrackingNet dataset.

1. Motivation

guideline:

  1. decomposition of classification and state estimation
    åˆ†è§£åˆ†ç±»ä¸çŠ¶æ€ä¼°è®¡ï¼šåˆ†ç±»å™¨ä¸“æ”»å°†ç›®æ ‡ç‰©ä½“ä¸èƒŒæ™¯åˆ†ç¦»ï¼Œè€ŒçŠ¶æ€ä¼°è®¡åˆ™æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†äº§ç”Ÿæ›´å‡†ç¡®çš„BBï¼Œé‚£äº›å¤šå°ºåº¦çš„æ–¹æ³•å¿½ç•¥äº†åé¡¹ï¼Œå› æ­¤ç²¾åº¦ä½ä¸‹ï¼›
  2. non-ambiguous scoring
    æ˜ç¡®åˆ†ç±»å¾—åˆ†ï¼šåˆ†ç±»å¾—åˆ°åº”è¯¥ç›´æ¥è¡¨ç¤ºä¸ºç›®æ ‡åœ¨è§†é‡ä¸­å­˜åœ¨çš„ç½®ä¿¡åº¦åˆ†æ•°ï¼Œè€Œä¸æ˜¯åƒé¢„å®šä¹‰çš„anchorä¸€æ ·è®¾ç½®ï¼Œå¯¹äºRPNçš„æ€æƒ³æå…¶å®¹æ˜“äº§ç”Ÿå‡é˜³æ€§æ ·æœ¬ï¼›
  3. prior knowledge-free
    å»é™¤å…ˆéªŒçŸ¥è¯†ï¼šè¿½è¸ªåº”è¯¥ç¬¦åˆé€šç”¨çš„ç²¾ç¥ï¼Œå³æ¯”ä¾‹ç­‰å› ç´ ä¸è¯¥æˆä¸ºæœç´¢æˆ–è€…æ£€æµ‹çš„å› ç´ ï¼ŒRPNçš„æ€æƒ³é˜»ç¢äº†è¿½è¸ªå™¨çš„æ³›åŒ–èƒ½åŠ›ï¼›
  4. estimation quality assessment
    ä½œè€…å€Ÿé‰´äº†IoU-Netå’ŒFCOSï¼Œå¢åŠ äº†è¯„ä¼°è´¨é‡çš„åˆ†æ”¯ï¼Œè¾¹ç•Œæ¡†è¿›è¡Œåˆ†ç±»ç½®ä¿¡åº¦ä¼šå¯¼è‡´æ€§èƒ½çš„ä¸‹é™ã€‚

2. Methods

architectureï¼š

2.1 Design follow Guidelines

ï¼ˆå…¶å®å°±æ˜¯anchor-freeæœºåˆ¶ + è´¨é‡åˆ†æ”¯ï¼‰

G1 : åˆ†ç±»å’ŒçŠ¶æ€ä¼°è®¡ä»»åŠ¡çš„åˆ†ç¦»

â€‹åˆ†ç±»ï¼šæ¯ä¸ªä½ç½®çš„å¾—åˆ† + å›å½’ï¼š4Då‘é‡offset

G2 : å¾—åˆ†æ— æ­§ä¹‰
ç›´æ¥å¯¹ç›¸åº”çš„å›¾åƒå—è¿›è¡Œåˆ†ç±»ï¼Œå¹¶åœ¨è¯¥ä½ç½®å›å½’ç›®æ ‡è¾¹æ¡†ï¼Œå³ç›´æ¥å°†ä½ç½®è§†ä¸ºè®­ç»ƒæ ·æœ¬ã€‚è€ŒåŸºäºé”šç‚¹çš„ç›®æ ‡ï¼ˆå°†è¾“å…¥å›¾åƒä¸Šçš„ä½ç½®è§†ä¸ºå¤šä¸ªé”šæ¡†çš„ä¸­å¿ƒï¼‰åœ¨ç›¸åŒä½ç½®ä¼šè¾“å‡ºå¤šä¸ªåˆ†ç±»å¾—åˆ†ï¼Œå¹¶æ ¹æ®é”šç‚¹å›å½’ç›®æ ‡è¾¹ç•Œæ¡†ï¼Œè¿™å¯¼è‡´äº†æ¯ä¸ªä½ç½®çš„æ­§ä¹‰æ€§ã€‚
G3 : æ— å…ˆéªŒ
æ²¡æœ‰é¢„è®¾çš„é”šç‚¹å’Œé˜ˆå€¼ï¼Œè‡ªç„¶æ²¡æœ‰äººå·¥å…ˆéªŒä¿¡æ¯ã€‚

G4 : é¢„æµ‹è´¨é‡çš„è¯„ä¼°ã€ç±»ä¼¼FCOSçš„center-nessåˆ†æ”¯ã€‘

â€‹ç›´æ¥ä½¿ç”¨åˆ†ç±»å¾—åˆ†æ¥é€‰æ‹©æœ€ç»ˆé¢„æµ‹è¾¹æ¡†ï¼Œå¯èƒ½ä¼šå¯¼è‡´å®šä½ç²¾åº¦é™ä½ï¼Œå› ä¸ºåˆ†ç±»ç½®ä¿¡åº¦ä¸å®šä½ç²¾åº¦æ²¡æœ‰å¾ˆå¥½çš„ç›¸å…³æ€§ã€‚å‡è®¾ç›®æ ‡ä¸­å¿ƒå‘¨å›´çš„ç‰¹å¾åƒç´ æ¯”å…¶ä»–åƒç´ å…·æœ‰æ›´å¥½çš„ä¼°è®¡è´¨é‡ã€‚åœ¨åˆ†ç±»headå¹¶è¡Œæ·»åŠ 1Ã—1å·ç§¯å±‚æ¥è¿›è¡Œè´¨é‡è¯„ä¼°ã€‚è¯¥è¾“å‡ºç”¨äºä¼°è®¡Prior Spatial Scoreï¼ˆPSSï¼‰ï¼Œå…¶å®šä¹‰å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

PSSâˆ—=min(lâˆ—,râˆ—)max(lâˆ—,râˆ—)Ã—min(tâˆ—,bâˆ—)max(tâˆ—,bâˆ—)PSS^*=\sqrt{\frac{min(l^*, r^*)}{max(l^*, r^*)}\times \frac{min(t^*, b^*)}{max(t^*, b^*)}}PSSâˆ—=max(lâˆ—,râˆ—)min(lâˆ—,râˆ—)â€‹Ã—max(tâˆ—,bâˆ—)min(tâˆ—,bâˆ—)â€‹â€‹

IoUä¹Ÿæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªè´¨é‡è¯„ä¼°çš„æŒ‡æ ‡ï¼š

IoUâˆ—=Intersection(B,Bâˆ—)Union(B,Bâˆ—)IoU^*=\frac{Intersection(B, B^*)}{Union(B, B^*)}IoUâˆ—=Union(B,Bâˆ—)Intersection(B,Bâˆ—)â€‹

æ¨ç†æ—¶æœ€åçš„å¾—åˆ†ç”±PSSä¹˜ä»¥å¯¹åº”çš„é¢„æµ‹åˆ†ç±»å¾—åˆ†ï¼ŒåŸç†ç‰©ä½“ä¸­å¿ƒçš„åƒç´ å°†ä¼šè¢«é™ä½æƒé‡ï¼Œä»¥æ­¤æé«˜ç²¾åº¦ã€‚

2.2 Training Objective

LclsL_{cls}Lclsâ€‹ : Focal loss

LqualityL_{quality}Lqualityâ€‹ : binary cross entropy(BCE) loss

LregL_{reg}Lregâ€‹: IoU loss

cx.yâˆ—c^*_{x.y}cx.yâˆ—â€‹ : 1 -> positive sample, 0 -> negative sample

3. Experiments

3.1 Training and Test

Model:

â€‹+AlexNet(8 layers) & +GoogLeNet(22 layers) [both pretrained on ImageNet]

â€‹â–¶ï¸ [lower computation cost, same or even better performance than previous methods using ResNet-50]

Training data:

â€‹ILSVRC-VID/DET, COCO, Youtube-BB, LaSOT, GOT-10k

Training phase:

â€‹For the AlexNet version, we freeze the parameters from conv1 to conv3 and fine-tune conv4 and conv5. For those layers without pretraining, we adopt a zero-centered Gaussian distribution with a standard deviation of 0.01 for initialization. We first train our model with for 5 warm up epochs with learning rate linearly increased from 10âˆ’710^{âˆ’7}10âˆ’7 to 2Ã—10âˆ’32 Ã— 10^{âˆ’3}2Ã—10âˆ’3, then use a cosine annealing learning rate schedule for the rest of 45 epochs, with 600k image pairs for each epoch. We choose stochastic gradient descent (SGD) with a momentum of 0.9 as the optimizer.

â€‹For the version implemented with GoogLeNet, we freeze stage 1 and 2, fine-tune stage 3 and 4, augment the base learning rate to 2Ã—10âˆ’22 Ã— 10^{âˆ’2}2Ã—10âˆ’2 , and multiply the learning rate of parameters in the backbone by 0.1 w.r.t the global learning rate. We also reduce the number of image pairs per epoch to 300k, reduce the total epoch to 20 (thus 5 for warming-up, and 15 for training) and unfreeze the parameters in backbone at the 10th epoch to avoid overfitting. For the experiment on LaSOT benchmark (Fan et al. 2019) (protocol II), we freeze the parameters in the backbone and further reduce the number of image pairs per epoch to 150k so that the training with the relatively smaller amount of training data could be stabilized.

Speed:

â€‹+AlexNet 160 FPS on the VOT2018

â€‹+GoogleNet 90 FPS on the VOT2018

â€‹ ğŸ–¥ evaluated on an NVIDIA RTX 2080Ti GPU.

Test phase:

â€‹ The output of our model is a set of bounding boxes with their corresponding confidence scores sss. Scores are penalized based on the scale/ratio change of corresponding boxes and distance away from the target position predicted in the last frame. Then the box with the highest penalized score is chosen and is used to update the target state.

3.2 Ablation study

â€‹(è¿™ä¸ªå’ŒSiamFCçš„æ¶ˆèå®éªŒåšçš„å¾ˆç§‘å­¦ã€‚å› ä¸ºæœ¬èº«trackerçš„è®­ç»ƒé›†å°±å¤§ï¼Œå› æ­¤é¦–å…ˆå°è¯•äº†SiamFCçš„è®­ç»ƒé›†æ‰©å……åˆ°åŒæ ·æ°´å¹³ï¼Œå†é€æ­¥è°ƒæ•´BackBoneå’Œå…¶ä»–çš„ä¸€äº›ç­–ç•¥ã€‚å¯ä»¥çœ‹åˆ°åˆ†æ•°æå‡æœ€æ˜æ˜¾çš„è¿˜æ˜¯å›å½’åˆ†æ”¯ã€‚)

The key components for tracking performance can be listed in descending order as follows:

  1. the regression branch (0.094),

  2. data source diversity (0.063/0.010),

  3. stronger backbone (0.026),

  4. and better head structure (0.020),

Data source diversity:

â€‹the augmentation of the diversity of training data significantly brings higher performance, which demonstrates the ability of our method to exploit rich offline training data.

Note:

1). the robustness Â® of Line 2 surpasses SiamRPN tracker (0.46);

2). the R of Line 3 is at the same level of DaSiamRPN (0.337) while using less data (without COCO and DET) than the latter.

â€‹These results indicate that, while the introduction of the RPN module and anchor boxes setting undoubtedly gives better accuracy, its robustness is not improved and even hindered. We owe this to its violation of our proposed guidelines. (è¿åäº†G3 æ— å…ˆéªŒä¿¡æ¯)

ï¼ˆATOMæœ‰åœ¨çº¿æ›´æ–°ï¼Œä½†æ•ˆæœä»å·®äºä¸æ›´æ–°çš„SiamFC++ï¼‰

SiamRPN drowbacks:

  • (G2) the classification score of SiamRPN represents the similarity between anchor and object, rather than template object and objects in search image, which may cause matching ambiguity;

  • (G3) the design of pre-set anchor boxes needs prior knowledge of the distribution of size and ratio of target;

  • (G4) the choice of target state estimation does not take estimation quality into consideration.

  • (SiamRPNfamilyadoptsproposalrefinement by the regression branch instead of the multi-scale test, and thus achieves astonishing tracking accuracy, which complies with our guideline G1)

â€‹Comparing SiamRPN++ and SiamFC++ scores, we can see that most classification score of SiamRPN++ follows similar and highly overlapped distributions, successful or not, while the classification score of our SiamFC++ of failure state exhibit very different pattern with that of a successful state.

â€‹As is shown from the IoU distribution, the prior knowledge given by anchor settings (violation of G3) leads to a bias in target state estimation. Concretely, the predicted box of SiamRPN++ tends to overlap more with the anchor box than with the ground truth box which can lead to performance degradation.

?

4. Appendices

Reference

  • SiamFC++ç¬”è®° https://blog.csdn.net/qq_35078996/article/details/106165540

entry.title: DaSiamRPN
entry.content:
ğŸ“„ paper: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1808.06048.pdf

ğŸ’» code: https://github.com/foolwood/DaSiamRPN

ğŸ“ slide: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1dsEI2uYHDfELK0CW2xgv7R4QdCs6lwfr

ğŸŒŸ ECCV 2018

Abstract

  • the imbalanced distribution of training data makes the learned features less discriminative.

    â€“> off-line + effective sampling strategy

  • novel distractor-aware module
    effectively transfer the general embedding to the current video domain.

  • local-to-global search region strategy

1. Introduction

Problems:

  1. The semantic backgrounds are always considered as distractors, and the performance can not be guaranteed when the backgrounds are cluttered. (è¯­ä¹‰èƒŒæ™¯ä¿¡æ¯(å³å¹²æ‰°ç‰©)æ²¡æœ‰å¾—åˆ°å……åˆ†æ¢ç´¢)

  2. these methods lose the ability to update the appearance model online which is often critical to account for drastic appearance changes in tracking scenarios. (ç¼ºå°‘æ›´æ–°ç­–ç•¥)

  3. local search strategy, which can not handle the full occlusion and out-of-view challenges. (åªæœ‰å±€éƒ¨æœç´¢)

2. Distractor-aware Siamese Networks

  1. Diverse categories of positive pairs can promote the generalization ability. (+VID / COCO datasets)

  2. Semantic negative pairs can improve the discriminative ability.
    two imbalance:

    • rare semantic negative pairs
    • intraclass distractors

  3. Customizing effective data augmentation for visual tracking.
    (translation, scale variations and illumination changes + motion blur)

3. Training

4. DaSiamRPN for Long-term Tracking

Extra challenges: out-of-view and full occlusion

Method: the local-to-global search region

5. Experiments

Ablation Study:

6. Reference

  • ECCVè§†è§‰ç›®æ ‡è·Ÿè¸ªä¹‹DaSiamRPN https://zhuanlan.zhihu.com/p/42546692
  • DASiamRPNé˜…è¯»ç¬”è®° https://blog.csdn.net/fzp95/article/details/82380261

entry.title: TADT
entry.content:
ğŸ“„ paper: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1904.01772.pdf

ğŸ’» code: https://github.com/ZikunZhou/TADT-python

ğŸŒŸ CVPR 2019

Abstract

[æå‡ºå¯¹é¢„è®­ç»ƒæ¨¡å‹çš„è´¨ç–‘ï¼Œå…³æ³¨ç‰¹å¾æå–çš„éƒ¨åˆ†]

â€‹Despite demonstrated successes for numerous vision tasks, the contributions of using pre-trained deep features for visual tracking are not as significant as
that for object recognition.

key issue :

  • in visual tracking, the targets of interest can be arbitrary object class with arbitrary forms.

  • pre-trained deep features are less effective in modeling these targets of arbitrary forms for distinguishing them from the background.

Contribution:

  • a novel scheme to learn target-aware features.
    (which can better recognize the targets undergoing significant appearance variations than pre-trained deep features.)
  • develop a regression loss and a ranking loss to guide the generation of target-active and scale-sensitive features.

æ˜¯å¦å¯ä»¥ç†è§£ä¸ºæœ¬è´¨ä¸Šæ˜¯é€šé“é—´çš„æ³¨æ„åŠ›ï¼Ÿ

1. Introduction

target: learn target-aware deep features.

â€‹The gradients obtained through back-propagating a classification neural network indicate class-specific saliency well[33]. (ç‰¹å®šç±»åˆ«çš„æ˜¾è‘—æ€§) With the use of global average pooling, the gradients generated by a convolutional filter can determine the importance of a filter for representing target objects.

[33]ï¼š Grad-CAM: Visual Explanations from Deep Networks via Gradient-based Localization

  • paper: https://openaccess.thecvf.com/content_ICCV_2017/papers/Selvaraju_Grad-CAM_Visual_Explanations_ICCV_2017_paper.pdf

  • supp: https://openaccess.thecvf.com/content_ICCV_2017/supplemental/Selvaraju_Grad-CAM_Visual_Explanations_ICCV_2017_supplemental.zip

  • code: https://github.com/ramprs/grad-cam/

  • blog: https://blog.csdn.net/u013738531/article/details/81322043

two types of objective losses:

  • hinge loss
    to regress pre-trained deep features to soft labels generated by a Gaussian function,
    use the gradients to select the target-active convolutional filters.
  • ranking loss
    with pair-wise distance to search for the scale-aware convolutional filters.

target-aware features vs. original deep features:

è¿™ä¸ªç»˜å›¾çš„æ€è·¯å¾ˆç‰¹åˆ«ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨äº†t-SNEé™ç»´ã€‚

target-awareå¯ä»¥æ‰©å¤§ç±»å†…å’Œç±»é—´çš„è·ç¦»ï¼ˆå³åŒºåˆ†åº¦æ›´é«˜ï¼‰

2. Method

2.1 Features of the pre-trained CNNs

issues:

  • the pre-trained CNN features are agnostic of the semantic and objectness information of the target, which most likely does not appear in the offline training data. (è¿½è¸ªéœ€è¦å¤„ç†ä»»ä½•å¯¹è±¡æ ‡ç­¾çš„ç›®æ ‡)
  • the pre-trained CNNs focus on increasing inter-class differences and the extracted deep features are insensitive to intra-class variations. ï¼ˆå¯¹ç±»é—´çš„ä¸åŒæ›´æ•æ„Ÿï¼Œå¯¹ç±»å†…çš„å˜åŒ–ä¸æ•æ„Ÿï¼‰
  • the pre-trained deep features are sparsely activated by each category label especially in a deeper convolutional network. ï¼ˆé¢„è®­ç»ƒçš„æ·±åº¦ç‰¹å¾è¢«æ¯ä¸ªç±»åˆ«æ ‡ç­¾ç¨€ç–æ¿€æ´»ï¼Œå³ç±»åˆ«é—´çš„å·®å¼‚ä¸»è¦å’Œå°‘æ•°ç‰¹å¾æœ‰å…³ï¼›å½“ç”¨äºè¿½è¸ªæ—¶ï¼Œåªæœ‰å°‘éƒ¨åˆ†è¢«æ¿€æ´»ï¼Œä¼šå¢åŠ è®¡ç®—é‡ï¼Œå¯¼è‡´è¿‡æ‹Ÿåˆï¼‰

â€‹Based on the gradient-based guidance, we construct a target-aware feature model with losses designed specifically for visual tracking.

2.2 Target-Active Features via Regression

å¦‚Fig.4Â©

2.3 Scale-Sensitive Features via Ranking

3. Tracking Process

overall framework:

3.1 Tracker initialization

  • The pre-trained feature extractor is offline trained on the classification task.
  • the target-aware part is only trained in the first frame.

â€‹In initial training, the regression loss and the ranking loss parts are trained separately and we compute the gradients from each loss once the networks are converged. With the gradients, the feature generation model selects a fixed number of the filters with the highest importance scores from the pre-trained CNNs.

â€‹The final target-aware features are obtained by stacking these two types of feature filters. Considering the scalar difference, these two types of features are re-scaled by dividing their maximal channel summation (summation of all the values in one channel).

å…·ä½“æ“ä½œå­˜åœ¨ç–‘é—®

3.2 Online detection

3.3 Scale evaluation

â€‹To evaluate the scale change of the target, we fix the size of the template and re-scale the feature map of the search region in the current frame to smaller,
larger, and fixed ones. During tracking, all these three feature maps are compared with the target template. The scale evaluation is performed by finding the score map containing the highest response.

4. Experiments

4.1 Results

4.2 Ablation Studies

entry.title: Ocean
entry.content:
ğŸ“„ paper: https://arxiv.org/pdf/2006.10721.pdf

ğŸ’» code: https://github.com/researchmm/TracKitht

ğŸŒŸ ECCV 2020 (Learning Object-aware Anchor-free Networks for Real-time Object Tracking)

Abstract

â€‹the further improvement of anchor-based Siamese trackers is restricted by the lagged tracking robustness.

â€‹Reason: reg network is only trained on the positive anchor boxes (i.e. IoU>= 0.6), difficult to refine the anchors whose overlap with the target objects are small.

â€‹This will cause tracking failures especially when the classification results are not reliable.

â€‹Method:

  1. instead of refining the reference anchor boxes, we directly predict the position and scale of target objects in an anchor-free fashion.

    (ä¸å®Œå…¨å‚è€ƒ anchorï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯ä»¥ anchor-free æ–¹å¼ç›´æ¥é¢„æµ‹ç›®æ ‡å¯¹è±¡çš„ä½ç½®å’Œæ¯”ä¾‹ã€‚ç”±äº groundtruth æ¡†ä¸­çš„æ¯ä¸ªåƒç´ å‡å—è¿‡è‰¯å¥½è®­ç»ƒï¼Œå› æ­¤è·Ÿè¸ªå™¨èƒ½å¤Ÿåœ¨æ¨ç†è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­çº æ­£ç›®æ ‡å¯¹è±¡çš„ä¸ç²¾ç¡®é¢„æµ‹ã€‚)

  2. introduce a feature alignment module to learn an object-aware feature from predicted bounding boxes.

    (å¼•å…¥ç‰¹å¾å¯¹é½æ¨¡å—ï¼Œä»¥ä»é¢„æµ‹çš„è¾¹ç•Œæ¡†ä¸­å­¦ä¹ å¯¹è±¡æ„ŸçŸ¥ç‰¹å¾ã€‚ç›®æ ‡æ„ŸçŸ¥åŠŸèƒ½å¯ä»¥è¿›ä¸€æ­¥æœ‰åŠ©äºç›®æ ‡å¯¹è±¡å’ŒèƒŒæ™¯çš„åˆ†ç±»ã€‚)

æ ¸å¿ƒï¼šç”¨regçš„ç»“æœæ¥æŒ‡å¯¼è°ƒæ•´clsï¼Œå¾—åˆ°æ›´ç²¾ç¡®çš„ç»“æœã€‚

1. Method

Question:

â€‹Can we design a bbox regressor with the capability of rectifying inaccurate predictions. (ä¿®æ­£æ€æƒ³)

Object-aware anchor-free networks(Ocean):

â€‹two branches: object-aware/regular-region cls + reg

1.1 Anchor-free Regression Network

Core idea:

â€‹estimate the distances from each pixel within the target object to the four sides of the GT bbox. <Fig.2(a)>

1.2 Object-aware Classification Network

â€‹prior works sample feature with a fixed regular region in the feature map. <Fig.2(b)>

not scalable to the change of object scale.

ğŸ’¡ like Deformable Convolution ?

â€‹Therefore, author propose to quip the regular sampling grid G with a spatial transformation Ï„\tauÏ„ to convert the sampling positions from the fixed region to the predicted region M. <Fig.2Â©>

cyan points: region sample (like RoI Align use Interpolation?)

purple points: sample fixed grid region.

formula:

Note: If Î”tâˆˆÏ„\Delta t\in \tauÎ”tâˆˆÏ„ is set to 0 in Eq.(2), the feature sampling mechanism is degenerated to the fixed sampling on regular points, generating the regular-region feature.

ğŸ”¥ â€‹ Why?

strength:

  • robust to the changes of object scales.
  • provides a global description of candidate targets.

2. Network Architecture

offline anchor-free model + online update model

OA.Conv(Object-aware): 1xconv (3x3)

[ä¸‹é¢çš„Convåº”è¯¥æ˜¯regular region feature]

Î¦\PhiÎ¦: single dilated conv (3x3)

  • cut off the last stage of the standard ResNet-50, only retain the first fourth stages as the backbone.
  • only performs over a single scale (i.e. the last stage)

Online Update:

  • train online branch with fast conjugate gradient algorithm during inference.

3. Loss Function

IoU loss + BCE (Binary cross-entropy) loss

reg loss:

cls loss on object-aware feature fff:

cls loss on regular-region feature fâ€²f^{'}fâ€²:

label:

objective function:

4. Experiments

Pytorch 1.1.0, 8 Tesla V100 GPUs + a Xeon E5-2690 2.60 GHz CPU

Ablation Study:

å‚è€ƒèµ„æ–™

  • https://cloud.tencent.com/developer/article/1662174

entry.title: PointTrack
entry.content:
Segment as Points for Efficient Online Multi-Object Tracking and Segmentation ã€PointTrackã€‘

ğŸ“„ paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.01550

ğŸ’» code: https://github.com/detectRecog/PointTrack (now unavailable)

ğŸŒŸ ECCV 2020

Abstract

â€‹As affected by the inherent receptive field, convolution based feature extraction inevitably mixes up the foreground features and the background features , resulting in ambiguities in the subsequent instance association.

â€‹tacking-by-points paradigm: 2D Point cloud representation

1. Method

â€‹Inspired by PointNet (3D point clouds)

1.1 Context-aware Instance Embeddings Extraction

blue point: center point P(ucF,vcF)P(u_c^F,v_c^F)P(ucFâ€‹,vcFâ€‹)

Learning four data modalities:

  1. Offset

  2. Color

    The ablation study shows that the color data are critical for accurate instance association.

  3. Category

    When the current instance is adjacent to other instances, for EiE_iEiâ€‹ lying on the nearby instances, the category data YEiY_{E_i}YEiâ€‹â€‹ together with the offset data OEiO_{E_i}OEiâ€‹â€‹ tell PointTrack both the relative position and the semantic class of nearby instances, which serve as strong clues for instance association.

  4. Position

    Since previous three data modalities focus on extracting features around CbC_bCbâ€‹ regardless of the position of CbC_bCbâ€‹ in the image plane, we encode the
    position of CbC_bCbâ€‹ into the position embedding MbM_bMbâ€‹ . Following [34], we embed the position of CbC_bCbâ€‹ (4-dim) into a high-dimensional vector (64-dim) to make it easier for learning by computing cosine and sine functions of different wavelengths.

Instance association:

â€‹similarity S is

1.2 Instance Segmentation with Temporal Seed Consistency

  • optical flow OOO between ITâˆ’1I^{T-1}ITâˆ’1 and ITI^TIT is estimated by VCN.

  • we synthesize the warped seed maps ST^=O(STâˆ’1)\hat{S^T}=O(S^{T-1})ST^=O(STâˆ’1) by exploiting OOO to warp STâˆ’1S^{T-1}STâˆ’1.

  • temporal consistency loss:

    (N is number of foreground pixels.)

2. Experiments

entry.title: CGACD
entry.content:
Correlation-Guided Attention for Corner Detection Based Visual Trackingã€CGACDã€‘

ğŸ“„ paper: https://openaccess.thecvf.com/content_CVPR_2020/papers/Du_Correlation-Guided_Attention_for_Corner_Detection_Based_Visual_Tracking_CVPR_2020_paper.pdf

supp: https://openaccess.thecvf.com/content_CVPR_2020/supplemental/Du_Correlation-Guided_Attention_for_CVPR_2020_supplemental.pdf

ğŸ“¹ video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GXsiMpAWr4k

ğŸ’» code: https://github.com/ohhhyeahhh/SiamCAR

ğŸŒŸ CVPR 2020

Abstract

â€‹ç›¸å…³æ€§æŒ‡å¯¼çš„æ³¨æ„åŠ› + cornerçš„anchor-freeæ£€æµ‹

ï¼ˆæ³¨æ„åŠ›æœºåˆ¶ + anchor-freeæœºåˆ¶ï¼‰

â€‹two-stage method

â€‹(1). extract RoI by Siamese network

â€‹(2). pixel-wise correlation-guided spatial attention module

â€‹speed: running at 70FPS

1. Introduction

Several limitations on existing Corner detection-based trackingï¼š

  • directly detect cornersï¼Œdifficulty distinguishing distractors and target from the crones.
  • not effectively explore the relationship between the template and the search image, spatial information about the corners not explicitly encoded in the correlation results.
  • not use powerful networks. (like ResNet)

Key innovation:

  • exploit the relationship between template and RoI.
  • pixel-wise correlation to calculate the similarity between each template feature maps and RoI feature maps. (encode spatial information)
  • channel-wise correlation to calculate the channel-wise similarity maps. (encode importance information of the various channels)

2. Network Architecture

  • max-pooling and average-pooling gather different clues about the channel importance.

  • Unlike traditional cross-correlation, pixel-wise correlation separately highlights different parts of the target in different similarity maps.

  • the hourglass-structure network learns spatial attention maps from the pixel-wise similarity maps, which adaptively attend to the top-left and botom-right corners.

  • Upsample: conv + nearest interpolation

3. Experiments

3.1 Method Analysis

  • exploitation of relationship

    comparison of different integrating template and search image approaches (PS / AUC on OTB2015 & UAV123)

  • structure of attention module

    cross-correlation vs. guide spatial and channel attention. seeâ¬†ï¸

  • siamese tracking module

    show the effectiveness croner detection module (â†‘4.0% in PS & â†‘4.8% in AUC )

  • feature from different layers

    compare performance from different layers of the backbone.

    (conv4 block is best!)

  • Impact of RoI augmentation

    (â†‘0.5% in PS & â†‘0.5% in AUC ) see â¬†ï¸

3.2 SOTA comparison

  • VOT2018

  • OTB2015

  • UAV123

  • LaSOT

  • TrackingNet

4. Supplementary Material

3. ä½¿ç”¨æ·±å±‚ç½‘ç»œ

â€‹æ–‡ä¸­å®éªŒä¸»è¦åœ¨ResNet-50ä¸Šè¿›è¡Œï¼Œç”±äºç°ä»£åŒ–ç½‘ç»œä¸€èˆ¬éƒ½æ˜¯ strideä¸º32ï¼Œä½†è·Ÿè¸ªä¸ºäº†å®šä½çš„å‡†ç¡®æ€§ï¼Œä¸€èˆ¬ stride éœ€è¦æ¯”è¾ƒå°ï¼ˆSiamese ç³»åˆ—ä¸€èˆ¬éƒ½ä¸º 8ï¼‰ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥æˆ‘ä»¬æŠŠ ResNet æœ€åä¸¤ä¸ª block çš„ stride å»æ‰ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶å¢åŠ äº† dilated convolutionï¼Œä¸€æ˜¯ä¸ºäº†å¢åŠ æ„Ÿå—é‡ï¼ŒäºŒæ˜¯ä¸ºäº†èƒ½åˆ©ç”¨ä¸Šé¢„è®­ç»ƒå‚æ•°ã€‚è®ºæ–‡ä¸­æåˆ°çš„ MobileNet ç­‰å…¶ä»–ç½‘ç»œä¹Ÿæ˜¯è¿›è¡Œäº†è¿™æ ·çš„æ”¹åŠ¨ã€‚å¦‚ä¸Šå›¾æ‰€ç¤ºï¼Œæ”¹è¿‡ä¹‹åï¼Œåé¢ä¸‰ä¸ª block çš„åˆ†è¾¨ç‡å°±ä¸€è‡´äº†ã€‚

1. Introduction

â€‹è·Ÿè¸ªå¯ä»¥çœ‹æˆæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªç‰¹æ®Šçš„æ£€æµ‹é—®é¢˜ï¼Œå³instance detectionã€‚ä¸»è¦çš„åŒºåˆ«åœ¨äºç›®æ ‡æ£€æµ‹å¯ä»¥å®šä½æŸäº›é¢„å®šä¹‰ç±»åˆ«çš„å¯¹è±¡ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”å…¶è¾“å‡ºä¸ä¼šåœ¨intra-classå®ä¾‹ä¹‹é—´è¿›è¡ŒåŒºåˆ†ï¼›ä½†æ˜¯ç›®æ ‡è¿½è¸ªä»…æŸ¥æ‰¾ç‰¹å®šå®ä¾‹ï¼Œè¯¥å®ä¾‹å¯èƒ½å±äºåˆå§‹å¸§ä¸­æŒ‡å®šçš„ä»»ä½•å·²çŸ¥æˆ–æœªçŸ¥çš„å¯¹è±¡ç±»åˆ«ã€‚

â€‹å› ä¸ºä¸¤è€…çš„ç›¸ä¼¼æ€§ï¼Œå¾ˆå¤šç›®æ ‡æ£€æµ‹çš„æŠ€æœ¯å¯ä»¥åº”ç”¨åœ¨ç›®æ ‡è¿½è¸ªä¸Šé¢ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚ï¼ŒFaster R-CNNä¸­çš„RPNç½‘ç»œåº”ç”¨åœ¨SiamRPNè¿½è¸ªå™¨åŠå…¶å˜ä½“ï¼›multi-aspect-ratio anchorsè§£å†³äº†å›°æ‰°ä¹‹å‰è¿½è¸ªå™¨çš„box estimationé—®é¢˜ï¼›IoU-Netä¹Ÿåº”ç”¨äºATOMå’ŒDiMPä¸­ã€‚

â€‹ç»™å®šåˆé€‚çš„åˆå§‹åŒ–ï¼Œæ£€æµ‹å™¨ä»å•å¸§ä¸­å¿«é€Ÿå­¦ä¹ å®ä¾‹ä¿¡æ¯ä»è€Œè½¬å˜æˆä¸€ä¸ªè·Ÿè¸ªå™¨ã€‚éš¾ç‚¹å°±åœ¨äºå¦‚ä½•ç»™è¿™ä¸ªåˆå§‹åŒ–ä½¿å¾—æ¨¡å‹åœ¨å°‘é‡æ ·æœ¬çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹å°±èƒ½å­¦åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªæ–°çš„instanceçš„ä¿¡æ¯è€Œä¸ä¼šè¿‡æ‹Ÿåˆï¼Œè¿™å°±æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªdomain adaptationçš„é—®é¢˜ï¼Œè€Œmodel-agnostic meta-learning (MAML) æ— ç–‘æ˜¯è§£å†³è¿™ç§é—®é¢˜çš„ä¸€ä¸ªåˆ©å™¨ã€‚

â€‹è¿™æ ·ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å°±å¯ä»¥å°†ä¸€ä¸ªæ£€æµ‹å™¨é€šè¿‡domain adaptationè½¬å˜æˆé€‚åˆæŸä¸ªç‰¹å®šdomain ï¼ˆæˆ–è€…è¯´æ˜¯instanceï¼‰çš„è·Ÿè¸ªå™¨ï¼Œä¸‹å›¾å½¢è±¡åœ°å±•ç¤ºäº†è¿™ä¸ªè¿‡ç¨‹ã€‚

å…·ä½“åº”ç”¨MAMLçš„å°†detectorè½¬å˜ä¸ºtrackerçš„æµç¨‹å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

  1. ä½¿ç”¨gradient descentè®­ç»ƒä¸€èˆ¬çš„æ£€æµ‹å™¨ï¼›

  2. ä½¿ç”¨MAMLåœ¨å¤§é‡è·Ÿè¸ªåºåˆ—ä¸Šç¦»çº¿è®­ç»ƒï¼›

  3. ç»™å®šæµ‹è¯•åºåˆ—ç¬¬ä¸€å¸§ä¿¡æ¯åï¼Œé€šè¿‡å‡ æ­¥gradient descent æ¥ fine-tuneæ¨¡å‹å‚æ•°åšdomain adaptationä»è€Œå¾—åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªè·Ÿè¸ªå™¨ã€‚è·Ÿè¸ªè¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­ï¼Œå½“ç›®æ ‡å¤–è§‚å‘ç”Ÿå˜åŒ–æ—¶ï¼Œå¯ä»¥ç”¨æ›´å¤šæ ·æœ¬è¿›è¡Œfine-tuneå¾—åˆ°æ›´å¥½çš„é€‚åº”èƒ½åŠ›ã€‚

2. Related Work

2.1 CNN-based visual object tracking

â€‹é¦–å…ˆä»‹ç»CNN-based trackersçš„ä¸€äº›å·¥ä½œï¼Œè¿™é‡Œä½œè€…æŒ‰ç…§æ˜¯å¦æ˜¾å¼çš„ä½¿ç”¨æ¨¡æ¿å°†å…¶åˆ†æˆäº†ä¸¤ç±»ã€‚

â€‹template-basedçš„æ–¹æ³•é€šå¸¸æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªæ¨¡æ¿åˆ†æ”¯ï¼Œå°†ç›®æ ‡å¤–è§‚ä¿¡æ¯å­˜å‚¨åœ¨æ˜¾å¼æ¨¡æ¿ä¸­ï¼Œå¦‚å¸¸è§çš„siameseç³»åˆ—çš„è·Ÿè¸ªå™¨ã€‚è¿™ç§æ–¹æ³•ä¼˜ç‚¹æ˜¯å¿«ï¼Œä¸éœ€è¦åœ¨çº¿æ›´æ–°ã€‚éš¾ç‚¹ä¹Ÿæ˜¯éš¾ä»¥æ‰¾åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªåˆé€‚çš„åœ¨çº¿æ›´æ–°æ–¹æ³•æ¥æ›´æ–°æ¨¡æ¿ï¼Œä»è€Œæ— æ³•é€‚åº”ä¸€äº›ç›®æ ‡çš„å˜åŒ–ã€‚(SiamFC, SiamRPN, SPM-Tracker, ATOM/DiMP)

â€‹å¦ä¸€æ–¹é¢template-freeçš„æ–¹æ³•å°±æ˜¯å°†ç›®æ ‡å¤–è§‚ä¿¡æ¯ä»¥å¾®è°ƒå‚æ•°çš„å½¢å¼å­˜å‚¨åœ¨ç½‘ç»œä¸­ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚MDNetã€‚ä½†è¿™ç±»ç®—æ³•çš„éš¾ç‚¹ä¸€ä¸ªæ˜¯æ…¢ï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªæ˜¯å®¹æ˜“è¿‡æ‹Ÿåˆï¼Œæ— æ³•å¾ˆå¥½å°†instanceä¿¡æ¯èåˆè¿›ç½‘ç»œã€‚

â€‹æœ¬æ–‡è®¾è®¡äº†ä¸€ä¸ªtemplate-free trackersï¼Œä½œè€…è®¤ä¸ºè¿™ç±»æ–¹æ³•çš„æ•´ä½“æ¶æ„å¯ä»¥å¾ˆå¥½çš„åŒ¹é…ä¸€ä¸ªæ£€æµ‹æ¡†æ¶ï¼Œä¸éœ€è¦é¢å¤–æ·»åŠ å…¶ä»–åˆ†æ”¯æ”¹å˜ç»“æ„ã€‚

2.2 Meta learning and its application to tracking

â€‹ä»‹ç»ä¸€äº›meta-learningçš„ç›¸å…³å·¥ä½œä»¥åŠåœ¨è·Ÿè¸ªä¸­çš„åº”ç”¨ï¼Œä¸è¿‡ç›®å‰è¿™ç§æ–¹æ³•åœ¨è·Ÿè¸ªä¸­çš„åº”ç”¨è¿˜ä¸å¤Ÿæˆç†Ÿï¼Œæœ‰äº›ç²¾åº¦ä¸å¤Ÿé«˜ï¼Œæœ‰äº›é€Ÿåº¦å¤ªæ…¢äº†ã€‚

â€‹Model-agnostic meta-learning (MAML) [10] is an im-
portant algorithm for meta learning. The most striking merit of MAML is that it is compatible with any model trained with gradient descent and applicable to a variety of different learning problems.
Because of this, MAML is a perfect candidate to realize our idea, which is to convert any advanced object detectors (trained with gradient descent) into a tracker.

MAML++

MetaSGD

â€‹Meta-Trackerç¬¬ä¸€æ¬¡ä½¿ç”¨MAMLä½œä¸ºMDNetçš„domain adaptation stepï¼›MetaRTTè¿›ä¸€æ­¥åº”ç”¨MAMLä½œä¸ºåœ¨çº¿æ›´æ–°æ­¥éª¤ï¼Œä»¥æ­¤åŠ é€Ÿç°æœ‰trackerçš„åœ¨çº¿è®­ç»ƒé€Ÿåº¦ã€‚

â€‹We argue that, since meta learning provides a mechanism to quickly adapt a deep network to model a particular object and avoid overfitting, why not directly convert a modern object detector into a tracker, instead of making a slow tracker faster?

â€‹Î±\alphaÎ±å’ŒÎ¸k\theta_kÎ¸kâ€‹æœ‰ç›¸åŒçš„sizeï¼ŒâŠ™\odotâŠ™è¡¨ç¤ºelement-wise productï¼Œè‹¥ä¸ºæ¯ä¸ªå‚æ•°è®¾ç½®å­¦ä¹ ç‡ä¼šä½¿æ¨¡å‹å¤§å°å¢åŠ ä¸€å€ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ä½œè€…è¿™é‡Œä½¿ç”¨äº†kernel-wiseçš„æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œç»™æ¯ä¸ªå·ç§¯æ ¸å®šä¹‰äº†å­¦ä¹ ç‡ã€‚ï¼ˆå¤§æ¦‚ï¼‰

4. Retina-MAML and FCOS-MAML

â€‹è¿™ä¸€èŠ‚å°±æ˜¯å…·ä½“å°†å¦‚ä½•é€šè¿‡å¼€å§‹æåˆ°çš„3ä¸ªæ­¥éª¤æ¥æ„å»ºè·Ÿè¸ªå™¨ã€‚åŒ…æ‹¬detector choices, offline training details å’Œ online tracking processã€‚

4.1 Detectors

Anchor-based vs Anchor-free

â€‹ä½œè€…åˆ†åˆ«é€‰å–äº†anchor-baseçš„RetinaNetå’Œanchor-freeçš„FCOSæ¥ä½œä¸ºæ£€æµ‹å™¨ã€‚ç”±äºè·Ÿè¸ªé€šå¸¸ä¼šæ ¹æ®ç›®æ ‡å¤§å°é€‰æ‹©ä¸€ä¸ªæœç´¢åŒºåŸŸç„¶åå°†å…¶resizeåˆ°å›ºå®šå¤§å°è¾“å…¥åˆ°ç½‘ç»œä¸­ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥ç›®æ ‡å°ºåº¦åœ¨è·Ÿè¸ªä»»åŠ¡ä¸­é€šå¸¸åˆ†å¸ƒæ¯”è¾ƒé›†ä¸­ï¼Œä¸éœ€è¦FPNè¿™æ ·çš„ç»“æ„ã€‚å¦å¤–å¯¹äºFCOSåªä¿ç•™äº†centerness æ¥é¢„æµ‹åˆ†ç±»å¾—åˆ†ï¼ˆFCOSç”¨äº†ä¸‰ä¸ªnetwork headï¼šä¸€ä¸ªcommon regression headå’Œä¸¤ä¸ªcenterness/classification headsï¼‰ï¼›Retinanetåªè®¾è®¡äº†ä¸€ä¸ª64Ã—64å¤§å°çš„anchorã€‚

â€‹æ•´ä½“ç½‘ç»œç»“æ„å¦‚ä¸‹å›¾4ï¼ŒResnet18ä½œä¸ºbackboneï¼Œå‰3ä¸ªblockåœ¨ImageNeté¢„è®­ç»ƒååœ¨ç¦»çº¿è®­ç»ƒæ—¶å†»ç»“ï¼Œblock5è¢«ä¸¢å¼ƒï¼Œblock4ï¼ˆé»„è‰²éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼‰å¤åˆ¶ä¸€ä»½åˆ†åˆ«ç‹¬ç«‹ä½œç”¨åœ¨åˆ†ç±»å’Œå›å½’ä¸Šã€‚

4.2 Offline MAML training

Loss definition:

  • Retina-MAML

    Focal loss (classification) + smooth L1 loss (regression)

  • FCOS-MAML

    L2 loss (centerness scores) + L1 loss (regression)

entry.title: DiMP
entry.content:
Learning Discriminative Model Prediction for Trackingã€DiMPã€‘

ğŸ“„ paper: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1904.07220.pdf

ğŸ’» code: https://github.com/visionml/pytracking

ğŸŒŸ ICCV 2019 Oral https://www.bilibili.com/video/BV1zJ411t7Kb

Abstract

â€‹Our architecture is derived from a discriminative learning loss by designing a dedicated optimization process that is capable of predicting a powerful model in only a few iterations. Furthermore, our approach is able to learn key aspects of the discriminative
loss itself.

[ â–¶running at over 40 FPS]

å•å¡GTX 1080

  • 57FPS âš¡ ResNet-18 as backbone

  • 43FPS âš¡ ResNet-50 as backbone

ä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯discriminative learningï¼Ÿ

å¯ä»¥æœ‰æ•ˆåœ°åˆ©ç”¨èƒŒæ™¯ä¿¡æ¯çš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

1. Introduction

Siameseç³»åˆ—çš„ä¸‰å¤§ç¼ºç‚¹ï¼š

  2. å› ä¸ºè·Ÿè¸ªä¸€èˆ¬éƒ½æ˜¯å¾ˆå¤šæ²¡æœ‰è§è¿‡çš„ç±»ï¼Œé€šè¿‡offlineå­¦ä¹ çš„ç›¸ä¼¼æ€§åº¦é‡å¯èƒ½ä¸æ˜¯å¾ˆé€‚ç”¨ï¼›ã€åˆ¤åˆ«æ€§å­¦ä¹ loss+åœ¨çº¿æ›´æ–°æœ€é€Ÿæ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™æ³•å¾®è°ƒã€‘
  3. Siameseçš„æ¡†æ¶æ²¡æœ‰ä¸€ä¸ªåˆé€‚çš„æ¨¡å‹æ›´æ–°æ–¹å¼ã€‚ã€ä¿ç•™50ä¸ªå†å²æ ·æœ¬å¸§ + æ¯20å¸§ä½¿ç”¨ä¸¤æ­¥æœ€é€Ÿä¸‹é™æ³•è¿­ä»£å¾®è°ƒtarget model f + æ£€æµ‹åˆ°distractor peakï¼ˆå¹²æ‰°ï¼‰æ—¶ä¸€æ­¥æœ€é€Ÿä¸‹é™è¿­ä»£ã€‘

â€‹we take inspiration from the discriminative learning procedures that have been successfully applied in recent trackers [26ï¼ˆMDNetï¼‰, 7ï¼ˆC-COTï¼‰, 4ï¼ˆATOMï¼‰].

two key design choices:

  1. we employ a steepest descent based methodology that computes an optimal step length in each iteration.
  2. we integrate a module that effectively initializes the target model.

benchmarkï¼š

    åœ¨è®­ç»ƒçš„æ—¶å€™å¾—åˆ°çš„ä¸€ä¸ªåŒ…å«è®­ç»ƒæ ·æœ¬é€šç”¨ä¿¡æ¯çš„ç‰¹å¾å›¾ï¼Œå¾—åˆ°ä¸åŒçš„è·Ÿè¸ªç›®æ ‡ä¹‹é—´çš„å…±åŒçš„ç‰¹å¾ã€‚ä¸€å¹…å›¾çš„ä¸åŒä½ç½®æ‰€è¡¨è¾¾çš„é‡è¦æ€§ä¸åŒï¼Œ è¯¥æ³¨æ„åŠ›æœºåˆ¶è¦æ»¡è¶³ä¸­å¿ƒä½ç½®æƒé‡å¤§äºå‘¨å›´ä½ç½®ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚é«˜æ–¯åˆ†å¸ƒï¼Œå®è´¨æ˜¯åˆ©ç”¨äº†ç›®æ ‡åœ¨ç›®æ ‡å›¾åƒä¸­å¿ƒä½ç½®çš„å…ˆéªŒçŸ¥è¯†ã€‚é€šè¿‡å­¦ä¹ ç”Ÿæˆä¸€ä¸ªç±»ä¼¼é«˜æ–¯æ¡†çš„ç»“æ„ï¼Œè¡¨å¾ç›®æ ‡çš„ç©ºé—´ä¿¡æ¯ï¼ˆå¯ç†è§£ä¸ºä¼ ç»Ÿç›¸å…³æ»¤æ³¢ä¸­çš„æœŸæœ›çš„é«˜æ–¯å“åº”çš„Mapï¼‰ã€‚

    2ã€ Residual Attentionï¼šï¼ˆè´Ÿè´£å­¦ä¹ ä¸åŒè·Ÿè¸ªç›®æ ‡çš„å·®å¼‚æ€§ï¼‰ã€å¾®è°ƒã€‘

    é€šè¿‡æ²™æ¼ç½‘ç»œå¾—åˆ°è·Ÿè¸ªç›®æ ‡ä¹‹é—´çš„å·®å¼‚çš„ç‰¹å¾å›¾ã€‚ç”¨äºè¡¨å¾ç›®æ ‡çš„è¯­ä¹‰ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œå¢åŠ åˆ¤åˆ«èƒ½åŠ›ã€‚

    ç»è¿‡å·ç§¯ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œæå–çš„ç‰¹å¾é€šå¸¸åŒ…å«å¤šä¸ªé€šé“channelï¼Œä¸åŒçš„é€šé“å¾—åˆ°çš„ç‰¹å¾å›¾ä¸ä¸€æ ·ï¼Œæ¯ä¸€å±‚é€šé“ä»£è¡¨æŸç§ç‰¹å®šçš„æ¨¡å¼ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚åœ¨ä¸åŒåœºæ™¯ä¸‹ï¼Œä¸åŒé€šé“å¯èƒ½å…·æœ‰ä¸åŒçš„å…·æœ‰ç›¸å¼‚çš„æ˜¾è‘—æ€§ï¼Œé€šè¿‡é€šé“æ³¨æ„åŠ›æœºåˆ¶æ¥é€‰å–å¯¹è·Ÿè¸ªæ•ˆæœæ¯”è¾ƒå¥½çš„é€šé“ï¼Œå‰”é™¤å™ªå£°é€šé“ã€‚

â€‹å¦ä¸€ç±»æ–¹æ³•ï¼ˆMDNetã€ECOã€ATOMï¼‰é€šè¿‡åœ¨çº¿å­¦ä¹ ä¸€ä¸ªdiscriminative classifieræ¥ä»èƒŒæ™¯ä¸­åŒºåˆ†ç›®æ ‡ã€‚è¯¥ç±»æ–¹æ³•å¯ä»¥æœ‰æ•ˆåœ°åº”ç”¨èƒŒæ™¯ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œå› æ­¤ç»“æœæ¯”è¾ƒé²æ£’ã€‚ç„¶è€Œï¼Œè¿™äº›æ–¹æ³•ä¾èµ–äºæ›´å¤æ‚çš„online learning procedureï¼Œä¸æ˜“ä½¿ç”¨end-to-endå­¦ä¹ æ¨¡å‹æ¥æè¿°ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œè¿™äº›æ–¹æ³•ç»å¸¸æ˜¯å±€é™äºä»é¢„è®­ç»ƒçš„æ·±åº¦ç½‘ç»œä¸­æå–ç‰¹å¾ã€‚

â€‹CFNetå°†CFçš„å•æ ·æœ¬é—­å¼è§£æ•´åˆåˆ°äº†æ·±åº¦ç½‘ç»œä¸­ï¼Œä½†è¿™ä¸ªç®€å•çš„CFæ¨¡å‹ç¼ºä¹åˆ¤åˆ«åŠ›ï¼Œæ•ˆæœæ¯”Siamese baselineå·®ã€‚RTINetåœ¨BACF Trackerä¸­å±•å¼€ADMMè¿­ä»£ï¼Œä»¥åœ¨å¤æ‚çš„å¤šé˜¶æ®µè®­ç»ƒä¸­å­¦ä¹ ç‰¹å¾æå–å™¨å’Œä¸€äº›è¶…å‚æ•°ã€‚ä½†BACFæ¨¡å‹ä»…é™äºå‚…é‡Œå¶åŸŸCFå…¬å¼çš„å•æ ·æœ¬å˜ä½“ï¼Œè¿™æ ·çš„å…¬å¼æ— æ³•åˆ©ç”¨å¤šä¸ªæ ·æœ¬ï¼Œéœ€è¦æ»¤æ³¢å™¨çš„ç‰¹æ®Šçº¿æ€§ç»„åˆæ‰èƒ½è¿›è¡Œæ¨¡å‹è°ƒæ•´ã€‚Meta-trackeræå‡ºäº†å°†å…ƒå­¦ä¹ è¿ç”¨åˆ°åˆå§‹ç›®æ ‡ç‹¬ç«‹æ¨¡å‹ä¸Šï¼Œç„¶åä½¿ç”¨å…·æœ‰å­¦ä¹ æ­¥é•¿çš„æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™è¿›è¡Œrefineã€‚ä½†æ­¤ç­–ç•¥ä»…é€‚ç”¨äºæ¨¡å‹çš„åˆå§‹é€‚åº”ï¼Œåœ¨ä»¥è¿­ä»£æ–¹å¼åº”ç”¨æ—¶è¡¨ç°æ²¡æœ‰æé«˜ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæ¨¡å‹ä¸å¯èƒ½å­¦ä¹ æ’å®šçš„æ­¥é•¿æ¥è¾¾åˆ°æ—¢èƒ½å¿«é€Ÿçš„åˆå§‹é€‚åº”ï¼Œåˆèƒ½optimal convergenceã€‚

entry.title: SiamR-CNN
entry.content:
Siam R-CNN: Visual Tracking by Re-Detection

paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/1911.12836

TF code: https://github.com/VisualComputingInstitute/SiamR-CNN

project: http://www.vision.rwth-aachen.de/page/siamrcnn

1. Introduction

â€‹æœ¬æ–‡åŸºäºçš„èŒƒå¼æ˜¯åˆ©ç”¨é‡æ£€æµ‹è¿›è¡Œè§†é¢‘ç›®æ ‡è¿½è¸ªã€‚å‰æœŸåˆ©ç”¨é‡æ£€æµ‹è¿›è¡Œè§†è§‰ç›®æ ‡è¿½è¸ªçš„æ–¹æ³•é€šå¸¸ä¼šå—åˆ°ç›¸ä¼¼å¹²æ‰°ç‰©çš„å½±å“ï¼Œå…¶è§£å†³ç­–ç•¥ä¸»è¦æ˜¯åˆ©ç”¨å…ˆå‰çš„é¢„æµ‹æä¾›å¼ºä½ç½®å…ˆéªŒä¿¡æ¯å’Œæ¨¡å‹åœ¨çº¿æ›´æ–°ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯è¿™ä¸¤ç§æ–¹æ³•éƒ½é¿å…ä¸äº†æ¨¡å‹çš„æ¼‚ç§»é—®é¢˜ã€‚

ä»€ä¹ˆæ˜¯re-detectï¼Ÿ

ä¸»è¦å·¥ä½œï¼š

  • æå‡ºä¸€ç§æ–°çš„Siam R-CNNè¿½è¸ªå™¨ï¼Œåˆ©ç”¨å­ªç”Ÿç»“æ„å°†Faster R-CNNåº”ç”¨äºè§£å†³è§†è§‰ç›®æ ‡è¿½è¸ªé—®é¢˜
  • æå‡ºä¸€ç§æ–°çš„éš¾ä¾‹æŒ–æ˜æ–¹æ³•ï¼Œèƒ½æœ‰æ•ˆç¼“è§£å¹²æ‰°ç‰©å¯¹è¿½è¸ªç»“æœçš„å½±å“
  • æå‡ºä¸€ç§åŸºäºTrackletsçš„åŠ¨æ€è§„åˆ’ç®—æ³•ï¼Œèƒ½å¤Ÿåœ¨é®æŒ¡ã€ç›®æ ‡æ¶ˆå¤±ç­‰æŒ‘æˆ˜ä¸­å®ç°æœ‰æ•ˆè¿½è¸ª

â€‹Siam R-CNNåœ¨å…­ä¸ªçŸ­æœŸè¿½è¸ªåŸºå‡†å’Œå››ä¸ªé•¿æœŸè¿½è¸ªåŸºå‡†ä¸­å‡ä¼˜äºå…ˆå‰æå‡ºçš„æ–¹æ³•ã€‚å¦å¤–ï¼Œåˆ©ç”¨ç°æœ‰çš„box-to-segmentationéƒ¨ä»¶èƒ½å¤Ÿåˆ©ç”¨è¿½è¸ªæ¡†å®ç°è§†é¢‘ç›®æ ‡åˆ†å‰²ï¼Œåœ¨å››ä¸ªå¸¸è§è¿½è¸ªæ•°æ®é›†ä¸Šæ¯”ä»…ä½¿ç”¨åˆå§‹æ¡†æ ‡æ³¨è¿›è¡Œåˆ†å‰²çš„å…¶ä»–æ–¹æ³•æ€§èƒ½éƒ½å¥½ã€‚

2. Related Work

â€‹Visual Object Tracking (VOT). VOTæ˜¯åœ¨ç»™å®šå¯¹è±¡ç¬¬ä¸€å¸§è¾¹ç•Œæ¡†çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹å®Œæˆè§†é¢‘ç›®æ ‡è¿½è¸ªä»»åŠ¡ã€‚ VOTé€šå¸¸æ ¹æ®åŸºå‡†è¿›è¡Œè¯„ä¼°ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚OTB [98ï¼Œ99]ï¼Œå¹´åº¦VOTæŒ‘æˆ˜[47ï¼Œ45]ï¼Œä»¥åŠæ›´å¤š[66ï¼Œ38ï¼Œ117ï¼Œ65ï¼Œ43]ã€‚ æœ€è¿‘ï¼Œå·²ç»æå‡ºäº†è®¸å¤šé•¿æœŸè·Ÿè¸ªåŸºå‡†[62ã€86ã€23]ï¼Œè¿™äº›åŸºå‡†å°†VOTæ‰©å±•åˆ°äº†æ›´åŠ å›°éš¾å’ŒçœŸå®çš„è®¾ç½®ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­å¿…é¡»åœ¨è®¸å¤šå¸§ä¸Šè·Ÿè¸ªå¯¹è±¡ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”å¯¹è±¡ä¼šæ¶ˆå¤±å¹¶é‡æ–°å‡ºç°ã€‚

â€‹è®¸å¤šç»å…¸æ–¹æ³•ä½¿ç”¨åœ¨çº¿å­¦ä¹ çš„åˆ†ç±»å™¨æ¥é‡æ–°æ£€æµ‹æ•´ä¸ªå›¾åƒä¸Šçš„æ„Ÿå…´è¶£å¯¹è±¡[1ã€28ã€2ã€76ã€30ã€77ã€42]ã€‚ ç›¸åï¼ŒSiam R-CNNé€šè¿‡ç¦»çº¿è®­ç»ƒæ¥å­¦ä¹ é¢„æœŸçš„å¤–è§‚å˜åŒ–è€Œä¸æ˜¯åœ¨çº¿å­¦ä¹ åˆ†ç±»å™¨ã€‚

â€‹ä¸ºäº†ä¸ºVOSä»»åŠ¡ç”Ÿæˆåˆ†å‰²æ©è†œï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä½¿ç”¨äº†æ¥è‡ªPReMVOS [60]çš„ç°æˆçš„è¾¹ç•Œæ¡†åˆ°åˆ†å‰²ï¼ˆBox2Segï¼‰ç½‘ç»œã€‚ Box2Segæ˜¯å…·æœ‰Xception-65 [16]ä¸»å¹²çš„å…¨å·ç§¯DeepLabV3 + [11]ç½‘ç»œã€‚ å®ƒå·²ç»åœ¨Mapillary [68]å’ŒCOCO [56]ä¸Šå—è¿‡è®­ç»ƒï¼Œå¯ä»¥ä¸ºè¾¹ç•Œæ¡†è¾“å‡ºæ©è†œã€‚ Box2Segé€Ÿåº¦å¾ˆå¿«ï¼Œåœ¨è·Ÿè¸ªä¹‹åè¿è¡Œå®ƒåªéœ€æ¯å¸§æ¯ä¸ªå¯¹è±¡0.025ç§’ã€‚ æˆ‘ä»¬ç»„åˆé‡å çš„æ©è†œï¼Œä»¥ä½¿åƒç´ è¾ƒå°‘çš„æ©è†œä½äºé¡¶éƒ¨ã€‚

Î¦l(z)=FTB(Î¦lâˆ’1(z),Ï†l(z))\Phi_l(z) = FTB(\Phi_{l-1}(z),\varphi_l(z))Î¦lâ€‹(z)=FTB(Î¦lâˆ’1â€‹(z),Ï†lâ€‹(z))

Î¦l(x)=FTB(Î¦lâˆ’1(x),Ï†l(x))\Phi_l(x) = FTB(\Phi_{l-1}(x),\varphi_l(x))Î¦lâ€‹(x)=FTB(Î¦lâˆ’1â€‹(x),Ï†lâ€‹(x))

2.3.1 FTB

å¼•ç”¨ï¼šç›®æ ‡æ£€æµ‹ä¸­one-stageå’Œtwo-stageæ–¹æ³•çš„åŒºåˆ«å°±åœ¨äºæœ‰æ²¡æœ‰RPNã€‚

derived by performing convolutions on Î¦l(z)Î¦_l (z)Î¦lâ€‹(z) and Î¦l(x)Î¦_l (x)Î¦lâ€‹(x).

â€‹æˆ‘ä»¬ç”¨AlA_lAlâ€‹è¡¨ç¤ºåœ¨é˜¶æ®µlllçš„anchor setã€‚æ ¹æ®åˆ†ç±»çš„å¾—åˆ†ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥è¿‡æ»¤æ‰è¯¥é›†åˆä¸­negative confidence å¤§äºé¢„å…ˆè®¾å®šçš„é˜ˆå€¼Î¸\thetaÎ¸çš„æ ·æœ¬ã€‚ç„¶åï¼Œå‰©ä¸‹çš„æ ·æœ¬å°±æ„æˆäº†æ–°çš„anchor set Al+1A_{l+1}Al+1â€‹ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”ç”¨äºè®­ç»ƒRPNl+1RPN_{l+1}RPNl+1â€‹ã€‚æ­¤å¤–ï¼Œä¸ºäº†æä¾›æ›´å¥½çš„åˆå§‹åŒ–ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¼˜åŒ–äº†Al+1A_{l+1}Al+1â€‹ ä¸­ anchorçš„center locationä»¥åŠsizeï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥äº§ç”Ÿäº†æ›´åŠ å‡†ç¡®çš„å®šä½ã€‚

2.3.2 Loss Function

RPNlRPN_lRPNlâ€‹çš„æŸå¤±å‡½æ•°ä¸ºï¼š

â€‹å…¶ä¸­ï¼Œrilâˆ—r_i^{l^*}rilâˆ—â€‹è¡¨ç¤º anchor i å’ŒGTä¹‹é—´çš„true distanceï¼ˆçœŸå®è·ç¦»ï¼Ÿï¼‰ã€‚æœä»å‰äººå·¥ä½œï¼Œä½œè€…ä¹Ÿå°†rilâˆ—r_i^{l^*}rilâˆ—â€‹è®¾ç½®ä¸º 4d å‘é‡ï¼Œå¦‚ä¸‹æ‰€ç¤ºï¼š

â€‹å…¶ä¸­ï¼Œx, y, w, h æ˜¯ BBox çš„ä¸­å¿ƒç‚¹åŠå…¶å®½é«˜ã€‚ä¸å¸¸è§„çš„å›ºå®šanchorä¸åŒï¼ŒC-RPNçš„anchorså¯ä»¥è¿›è¡Œå¾®è°ƒï¼š

ã€æ³¨ã€‘æ­¤å¤„å…³äºæŸå¤±å‡½æ•°è®²çš„ä¸æ˜¯ç‰¹åˆ«æ¸…æ™°ï¼Œå…³äºå›å½’æŸå¤±å‡½æ•°çš„å®šä¹‰ï¼Œå¯ä»¥å‚è€ƒ

å¹¶ä¸”ä¸¤éƒ¨åˆ†æŸå¤±éƒ½åŒ…æ‹¬åˆ†ç±»æŸå¤±ï¼ˆcls lossï¼‰å’Œå›å½’æŸå¤±ï¼ˆbbox regression lossï¼‰ã€‚

entry.title: Deep Visual Tracking Review
entry.content:
Deep Visual Tracking: Review and Experimental Comparison

Peixia Li, Dong Wang, Lijun Wang, Huchuan Lu

School of Information and Communication Engineering, Faculty of Electronic Information and Electrical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, China

å¤§è¿ç†å·¥å¤§å­¦ä¿¡æ¯ä¸é€šä¿¡å·¥ç¨‹å­¦é™¢ï¼Œç”µå­ä¿¡æ¯ä¸ç”µæ°”å·¥ç¨‹å­¦é™¢ï¼Œå¤§è¿ç†å·¥å¤§å­¦ï¼Œä¸­å›½å¤§è¿

paperï¼šhttps://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0031320317304612

Abstract

  1. ä½¿ç”¨CNNå¯ä»¥æå¤§æå‡trackingæ€§èƒ½ã€‚
  2. ä½¿ç”¨CNNå¯ä»¥ä»surrounding backgroundä¸­å¾—åˆ°æ›´ç²¾ç¡®çš„tracked objectç»“æœï¼›ä½¿ç”¨CNNçš„æ¨¡æ¿åŒ¹é…é€šå¸¸ä¹Ÿä¼šæ›´å¿«ã€‚
  3. æ·±åº¦ç‰¹å¾æ˜æ˜¾ä¼˜äºæ‰‹å·¥ç‰¹å¾ã€‚
  4. ä¸åŒå±‚æ¬¡å·ç§¯å±‚å¾—åˆ°çš„ç‰¹å¾æœ‰ä¸åŒçš„ç‰¹ç‚¹ï¼ˆä½å±‚æ¬¡ç©ºé—´ç‰¹å¾ã€é«˜å±‚æ¬¡è¯­ä¹‰ç‰¹å¾ï¼‰ï¼Œæœ‰æ•ˆåœ°ç»¼åˆä¼šä½¿trackeræ›´é²æ£’ã€‚
  5. ç«¯åˆ°ç«¯çš„ç½‘ç»œé€šå¸¸ä¼šæ¯”ç‰¹å¾æå–ç½‘ç»œæ•ˆæœæ›´å¥½ã€‚
  6. æœ€é€‚åˆçš„è®­ç»ƒæ–¹æ³•æ˜¯ï¼šå…ˆåœ¨è§†é¢‘ä¿¡æ¯ä¸Šé¢„è®­ç»ƒï¼Œç„¶åå†ç»“åˆsubsequent observationï¼ˆå­åºåˆ—ä¿¡æ¯ï¼‰åœ¨çº¿fine-tuneï¼ˆVP-OLï¼‰ã€‚

1. Introduction

2.1 æ•´ä½“æ¶æ„

â€‹å°†å½“å‰å¸§çš„å›¾ç‰‡ï¼ˆä»¥åŠGTï¼‰è¾“å…¥åˆ°backboneæå–ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œå¾—åˆ°äº†Modulation vectorï¼Œæ¥ä¸‹æ¥test imageä¹Ÿè¾“å…¥åˆ°backboneä¸­æå–ç‰¹å¾ï¼Œç„¶åå°†layer 3å±‚çš„ç‰¹å¾ç»è¿‡åˆ†ç±»æ¨¡å—ï¼ˆclassifierï¼Œtrained onlineï¼‰ï¼Œé¢„æµ‹ç›®æ ‡çš„ä¸€ä¸ªç½®ä¿¡åº¦åˆ†æ•°ï¼ˆpositive coefficientsï¼‰ï¼Œä»è€Œå¾—åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªç²—ç•¥çš„BB estimatesï¼ˆä½ç½®å’Œå®½é«˜ï¼‰ã€‚

å½“ç„¶åœ¨è·Ÿè¸ªçš„æ—¶å€™IoU-Netæ˜¯ä¸æ›´æ–°çš„ï¼Œåªæ›´æ–°åˆ†ç±»çš„ä¸¤å±‚ï¼Œè¿™éƒ¨åˆ†ä»£ç ä½“ç°åœ¨åˆå§‹åŒ–IoU-Netçš„æ—¶å€™atom.pyä¸­çš„def init_iou_net()æ–¹æ³•ä¸­çš„``p.requires_grad=Falseå¦å¤–åœ¨pytrakcing/utils/loadingä¸­net, _ = ltr_loading.load_network(path_full, backbone_pretrained=False)`è¯´æ˜backoneä¸é‡‡ç”¨é¢„è®­ç»ƒæ¨¡å‹ï¼Œè€Œåœ¨è®­ç»ƒçš„æ—¶å€™backboneåŠ è½½çš„æ˜¯é¢„è®­ç»ƒæ¨¡å‹ã€‚

â€‹å…¶æ¬¡ï¼ŒåŸæ¥çš„IoU-Netæ˜¯é’ˆå¯¹class-specialçš„ï¼Œè€Œè·Ÿè¸ªé’ˆå¯¹äºä»»æ„ç±»éƒ½å¯ä»¥ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œåˆ©ç”¨äº†ç¬¬ä¸€å¸§ç›®æ ‡çš„æ ‡æ³¨ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œè·å–targe-specificä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œä»è€Œå¾—åˆ°ç›¸åº”çš„IoU predictionsã€‚å› æ­¤åœ¨è·Ÿè¸ªæ—¶ï¼Œç»™å®šç¬¬ä¸€å¸§çš„ä¿¡æ¯å¾ˆé‡è¦ï¼Œé‚£æ€ä¹ˆå¯ä»¥æœ‰æ•ˆåˆ©ç”¨å‘¢ï¼Ÿ

â€‹æœ¬æ–‡è¯•ç€å’Œå½“å‰å¸§çš„ç‰¹å¾èåˆï¼Œä½†æ˜¯æ•ˆæœå¾ˆå·®ï¼Œæœ€åæå‡ºäº† modulation-base networkæ¶æ„æ¥é¢„æµ‹ä»»æ„ç‰©ä½“çš„IoUã€‚æˆ‘è§‰å¾—è¿™é‡Œæ˜¯ä½œä¸ºä¸€ä¸ªå…ˆéªŒæ¡ä»¶çš„ï¼Œå…·ä½“çš„ç›®æ ‡ä¼°è®¡ç½‘ç»œï¼ˆè®­ç»ƒæ¡†æ¶ï¼‰å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

â€‹è¯¥ç½‘ç»œåŒ…å«ä¸¤ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯ï¼šreference branchå’Œtest branchï¼Œä¸¤ä¸ªåˆ†æ”¯éƒ½æ˜¯ä¾èµ–äºResNet-18 Block 3å’ŒResNet-18 Block 4çš„featureä½œä¸ºè¾“å…¥ã€‚

ã€è¡¥å……ã€‘

â€‹è¿½è¸ªé’ˆå¯¹çš„ç›®æ ‡ç±»åˆ«æ˜¯æœªçŸ¥çš„ï¼Œè€Œæ£€æµ‹é—®é¢˜æ˜¯ä¾èµ–äºæ¯ä¸ªç±»åˆ«ä¸Šçš„æ£€æµ‹ã€‚

è®ºæ–‡è¯´åŸæœ‰çš„IoU-Netæ˜¯class-specificçš„ï¼ŒåŸå› å°±åœ¨äºæ­¤ã€‚

â€‹ä½†ä»éœ€è¦class-specific IoU predictoræ¥å¯¹æ¯ä¸€å¸§è¿›è¡Œåˆ†æå¾—åˆ°high-level natureã€‚å› ä¸ºè¿™ä¸ªè®­ç»ƒè¿‡ç¨‹å¤ªè´¹æ—¶ï¼Œæ•…è€Œé‡‡ç”¨offline trainingæ¥å­¦ä¹ general representationç”¨äºIoU predictorã€‚

2.1.1 Reference Branch

ç”±ä¸€ä¸ªå·ç§¯å±‚åæ¥PrPoolå±‚å’Œå…¨è¿æ¥å±‚ç»„æˆã€‚

  • input

    Feature x0x_0x0â€‹ and the target bbox annotation B0B_0B0â€‹ in the reference image.

  • output

    Modulation Vector c(x0,B0)c(x_0,B_0)c(x0â€‹,B0â€‹) ï¼Œsizeï¼š1Ã—1Ã—Dz1\times1\times D_z1Ã—1Ã—Dzâ€‹

2.1.2 Test Branch

â€‹The current image, in which we want to estimate the target bounding box, is processed through the test branch.

â€‹ It first extracts a deep representation by feeding the backbone features xxx through two convolutional layers followed by a PrPool with the bounding box estimate B.

â€‹ç”±ä¸¤ä¸ªå·ç§¯å±‚ï¼Œåæ¥PrPoolç»„æˆã€‚

  • input

    backbone features xxx ï¼ˆdeep representationï¼‰

  • output

    representation z(x,B)z(x, B)z(x,B) ï¼Œsizeâ€‹ï¼šKÃ—KÃ—DzK\times K\times D_zKÃ—KÃ—Dzâ€‹

    where K is spatial output size of the PrPool layer

2.1.3 åç»­æ­¥éª¤

â€‹The computed feature representation of the test image is then modulated by the coefficient vector ccc via a channel-wise multiplication.

â€‹This creates a target-specific representation for IoU prediction, effectively incorporating the reference appearance information. The modulated representation is finally fed to the IoU predictor module ggg, consisting of three fully connected layers. The predicted IoU of the bounding box BBB is hence given by

IoU(B)=g(c(x0,B)â‹…z(x,B))IoU(B)=g(c(x_0, B)\cdot z(x,B))IoU(B)=g(c(x0â€‹,B)â‹…z(x,B))

é—®é¢˜ï¼šä¸çŸ¥é“gæ˜¯æŒ‡å“ªéƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Ÿè‡ªå·±ç†è§£æœ‰æ— åå·®ï¼Ÿ

å›ç­”ï¼šæš‚æ—¶æ— åå·®ã€‚

é—®é¢˜ï¼šè¿™ä¸¤ä¸ªbranchå„è‡ªå¯¹åº”äº†target estimationå’Œtarget classificationä¸­çš„å“ªä¸ªéƒ¨åˆ†ï¼Ÿ

å›ç­”ï¼štarget estimationï¼Œè´Ÿè´£ä¼°è®¡ç›®æ ‡çš„ä½ç½®ã€‚

2.1.4 PrPoolå‚è€ƒ

2.2 æ¨¡å‹è®­ç»ƒ

2.2.1 off-line trainingï¼ˆtarget estimationï¼Ÿï¼‰

è®­ç»ƒæ•°æ®é›†ï¼š

  • LaSOT datasetï¼ˆLarge-scale Single Object
    Trackingï¼‰
  • TrackingNet

â€‹åœ¨æœ€å¤§é—´éš”ä¸º50çš„è§†é¢‘ä¸­é‡‡æ ·å›¾ç‰‡å¯¹ï¼ŒåŒæ—¶ç”¨COCOæ•°æ®é›†åšæ•°æ®å¢å¼ºï¼Œæå–äº†ç›®æ ‡å‘¨å›´çš„5å€å¤§å°çš„æ–¹å½¢åŒºåŸŸä½œä¸ºè¾“å…¥

åŸæ–‡ä¸­ä¸º From the reference image, we sample a square patch centered at the target, with an area of about 525^252 times the target area.

â€‹åŒæ—¶ä¸ºäº†é˜²æ­¢ä»¥ç›®æ ‡ä¸ºä¸­å¿ƒè¿‡æ‹Ÿåˆï¼Œåœ¨test imageå¯¹positionå’Œscaleåšäº†æŠ–åŠ¨ï¼ˆperturbationï¼‰ã€‚

â€‹å› ä¸ºæ²¡æœ‰åˆ†ç±»å±‚é¢„æµ‹bboxï¼Œå› æ­¤åœ¨è®­ç»ƒçš„æ—¶å€™å°†test imageçš„bboxçœŸå€¼é€šè¿‡å¢åŠ é«˜æ–¯å™ªå£°åšäº†æ‰°åŠ¨ï¼Œäº§ç”Ÿäº†16 candidate bounding boxeï¼Œä¹‹åè¿˜ä½¿ç”¨image flipping and color jittering for data augmentationï¼Œä»è€Œè¾“å…¥åˆ°ç½‘ç»œä½œä¸ºåˆ†ç±»çš„ç»“æœã€‚è€Œtest imageçš„çœŸå€¼å’Œæ‰°åŠ¨åçš„å€¼åšäº†IoUï¼Œä»è€Œä½œä¸ºlossè¿›è¡Œè®­ç»ƒã€‚

å¦å¤–æˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥ä»ä¼˜åŒ–å™¨éƒ¨åˆ†çœ‹åˆ°ï¼Œè®­ç»ƒçš„æ—¶å€™æ›´æ–°çš„æ˜¯å“ªä¸€å—ï¼šoptimizer=optim.Adam(actor.net.bb_regressor.parameters(),lr=1e-3)ï¼Œä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯è®­ç»ƒiouneté‚£ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ã€‚

è®­ç»ƒå‚æ•°è®¾ç½®ï¼š

â€‹The weights in our head network are initialized using[12]. For the backbone network, we freeze all weights during training. We use the mean-squared error loss function and train for 40 epochs with 64 image pairs per batch. The ADAM [16] optimizer is employed with initial learning rate of 10âˆ’310^{âˆ’3}10âˆ’3 , and using a factor 0.2 decay every 15 epochs.

2.2.2 online trackingï¼ˆTarget Classification by Fast Online Learningï¼‰

â€‹åˆ†ç±»æ¨¡å‹ç”±ä¸¤å±‚å…¨å·ç§¯ç½‘ç»œç»„æˆï¼Œå¦‚å…¬å¼ï¼š

f(x;w)=Ï•2(w2âˆ—Ï•1(w1âˆ—x))f(x;w)=\phi_2 (w_2 * \phi_1 (w_1 * x))f(x;w)=Ï•2â€‹(w2â€‹âˆ—Ï•1â€‹(w1â€‹âˆ—x))

  • first layerï¼šï¼ˆ1Ã—1ï¼Œ64ï¼Œw1ï¼‰ï¼ˆ1\times1ï¼Œ64ï¼Œw_1ï¼‰ï¼ˆ1Ã—1ï¼Œ64ï¼Œw1â€‹ï¼‰

  • second layerï¼š$ï¼ˆ4\times4ï¼Œ1ï¼Œw_2) $

â€‹xæ˜¯backbone feature mapï¼Œç”±äºè®­ç»ƒæ ·æœ¬ä¸Šå¾—ä¸åˆ°åœ¨çº¿è·Ÿè¸ªç›®æ ‡çš„ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥åˆ†ç±»ç½‘ç»œçš„headæ˜¯åœ¨çº¿è®­ç»ƒçš„ï¼Œw1,w2w_1,w_2w1â€‹,w2â€‹æ˜¯ç½‘ç»œå‚æ•°ï¼Œâˆ—*âˆ—ä»£è¡¨standard multi-channe convolutionï¼ˆå¤šé€šé“å·ç§¯ï¼‰ã€‚

Learning objective based on the L2L^2L2 classification errorï¼š

â€‹Each training sample feature map xjx_jxjâ€‹ is annotated by the classification confidences yjâˆˆRWÃ—Hy_j \in \mathbb{R}^{W\times H}yjâ€‹âˆˆRWÃ—H, set to a sampled Gaussian function centered at the target location. The impact of each training sample is controlled by the weight Î³jÎ³_jÎ³jâ€‹, while the amount of regularization on wkw_kwkâ€‹ is set by Î»kÎ»_kÎ»kâ€‹ .

â€‹é€šå¸¸æˆ‘ä»¬ä¼šåº”ç”¨æ ‡å‡†çš„æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™æˆ–è€…éšæœºæ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™æ³•(SGD)æ³•æ±‚è§£ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯è¿™äº›ä¸é€‚åˆäºåœ¨çº¿å­¦ä¹ ï¼Œå› ä¸ºæ”¶æ•›æ•ˆç‡å¤ªæ…¢ã€‚æœ¬æ–‡ä½œè€…æå‡ºäº†å°†å…±è½­æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™æ³•ä¸ç¥ç»ç½‘ç»œçš„åå‘ä¼ æ’­ç»“åˆèµ·æ¥çš„æ–°æ–¹æ³•ã€‚

2.2.3 å…±è½­æ¢¯åº¦ä¸‹é™æ³•ï¼ˆConjugate Gradientï¼‰

å°†ä¸Šå¼åˆ—å‡ºçš„åˆ†ç±»æŸå¤±åˆ†ä¸ºä¸¤ä¸ªéƒ¨åˆ†ï¼š

for j âˆˆ {1,â€¦,m}, k = 1,2

æ‰€ä»¥æœ€åçš„æŸå¤±å‡½æ•°

â€‹å°±å¯ä»¥å†™ä½œL(w)=âˆ£âˆ£r(w)âˆ£âˆ£2L(w)=||r(w)||^2L(w)=âˆ£âˆ£r(w)âˆ£âˆ£2ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­r(w)r(w)r(w) is the concatenation of all residuals rj(w)r_j(w)rjâ€‹(w).

åˆ©ç”¨quadratic Gauss-Newtonï¼ˆè¿‘ä¼¼å¿½ç•¥äºŒé˜¶å¾®åˆ†ï¼‰è¿‘ä¼¼å¾—åˆ°:

è¿›è¡Œä¸€é˜¶æ³°å‹’å±•å¼€ï¼š

æœ€ç»ˆæŸå¤±å‡½æ•°çš„å…¬å¼å¯ä»¥åŒ–ä¸ºï¼š

â€‹we have defined rw=r(w)r_w = r(w)rwâ€‹=r(w) and Jw=âˆ‚râˆ‚wJ_w=\frac{âˆ‚r}{âˆ‚w}Jwâ€‹=âˆ‚wâˆ‚râ€‹ is the Jacobian of rrr at www ï¼ˆé›…å¯æ¯”çŸ©é˜µï¼‰. The new variable âˆ†wâˆ†wâˆ†w represents the increment in the parameters www.

entry.title: IoU-Net
entry.content:
Acquisition of Localization Confidence for Accurate Object Detectionï¼ˆIoU-Netï¼‰

Borui Jiang*, Ruixuan Luo*, Jiayuan Mao*, Tete Xiao, Yuning Jiang* (* indicates equal contribution.)

paperï¼šhttps://arxiv.org/abs/1807.11590

codeï¼šhttps://github.com/vacancy/PreciseRoIPooling

1. Introduction

1.1 ä¼ ç»Ÿæ–¹æ³•

â€‹ç°é˜¶æ®µçš„two-stageç›®æ ‡æ£€æµ‹å™¨ä¸»è¦æ˜¯è§£å†³multi-task learning problemï¼š

  1. distinguish foreground object proposals from background and assign them with proper class labels.
  2. regress a set of coefficients which localize the object by maximizing intersection-over-union (IoU) or other metrics between detection results and the ground-truth.

ä»»åŠ¡æµç¨‹ï¼š

  1. RPNæ‰¾å‡ºä¸€ç³»åˆ—å€™é€‰æ¡†ï¼ŒåŒºåˆ†å‰æ™¯èƒŒæ™¯ã€‚
  2. å¯¹å‰æ™¯æ¡†è¿›è¡Œåˆ†ç±»å’Œå›å½’ï¼Œå¾—åˆ°æ¯ä¸ªæ¡†çš„åˆ†ç±»ç½®ä¿¡åº¦åŠå›å½’åæ ‡ã€‚
  3. é€šè¿‡NMSï¼Œä»¥åˆ†ç±»ç½®ä¿¡åº¦æ’åºï¼Œè¿‡æ»¤æ‰IoUå¤§äºä¸€å®šé˜ˆå€¼çš„æ¡†ï¼Œå¾—åˆ°æœ€ç»ˆçš„ç»“æœ ã€‚

ä¾‹å¦‚FRCNNï¼š

â€‹å¹¶è¡Œè¾“å‡ºä¸¤ä¸ªä»»åŠ¡ï¼šcls score + bbox offsetï¼Œè°ƒæ•´å¥½bboxä½ç½®ï¼Œå†åšNMSå‰”é™¤å†—ä½™bboxã€‚

ä¼ ç»Ÿçš„NMSï¼š

  • classification confidenceï¼ˆæœ‰ï¼‰

    ç»™æ¯ä¸ªproposalæ‰“class labelï¼Œæœ€åä½¿ç”¨bbox regressionæ¥æ‰¾åˆ°æœ€ç¬¦åˆGTçš„ä½ç½®ï¼Œæœ€åï¼Œé€šè¿‡NMSæ¶ˆé™¤å†—ä½™çš„bboxã€‚

  • localization confidenceï¼ˆæ— ï¼‰

1.1.1 ä¼ ç»Ÿæ–¹æ³•ç¼ºé™·

ç”±æ­¤å¸¦æ¥çš„ç¼ºç‚¹ï¼š

  1. åªç”¨classification confidenceä½œä¸ºmetric for ranking the proposalsã€‚è€Œå¿½ç•¥äº†localization accuracyï¼Œä¼šå¯¼è‡´IoUæ›´å¤§ä½†cls scoreæ›´å°çš„æ¡†åœ¨NMSä¸­è¢«æŠ‘åˆ¶ã€‚

â€œbad money drives out goodâ€

â€‹ the misalignment between classification confidence and localization accuracy may lead to accurately localized bounding boxes being suppressed by less accurate ones in the NMS procedure.

  1. ç¼ºä¹localization confidenceä½¿bbox regressionè§£é‡Šæ€§å˜å·®ï¼›è€Œä¸”å¤šæ¬¡è¿ç”¨bbox regä¼šä½¿bboxå®šä½ç²¾åº¦ä¸‹é™ã€‚

non-monotonicity of iterative bounding box regressionï¼ˆéå•è°ƒæ€§ï¼‰

â€‹That is, bounding box regression may degenerate the localization of input bounding boxes if applied for multiple times.

1.2 IoU-Net

â€‹IoU-Netä½¿ç”¨å¾…æ£€æµ‹bboxå’Œground-truth boxçš„IoUä½œä¸º localization criterionï¼Œå¯ä»¥è§£å†³å‰é¢æåˆ°çš„é—®é¢˜ã€‚

  1. IoU-guided NMS

    â€‹IoUæ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªnatural criterion for localization accuracyï¼Œä½¿ç”¨predicted IoUä½œä¸ºranking keyword in NMS

  2. Precise RoI Pooling

    â€‹ä½¿ç”¨optimization-based bounding box refinement procedureæ›¿ä»£åŸæœ‰çš„ traditional regression-based methodï¼Œä½¿ç”¨predicted IoUä½œä¸ºoptimization objectiveï¼Œå¯¹äºlocalization confidenceä¹Ÿæœ‰å¾ˆå¥½çš„è§£é‡Šæ€§ï¼›å¹¶ä¸”æä¾›ä¸€ä¸ªmonotonic improvementã€‚

    â€‹PrRoI Pooling layerä½¿ç”¨æ¢¯åº¦ä¸Šå‡æ³•è§£å†³IoUä¼˜åŒ–é—®é¢˜ã€‚

2. Object Localization

â€‹A standard FPN detector is trained on MS-COCO
trainval35ktrainval35ktrainval35k as the baseline and tested on minivalminivalminival for the study.

2.1 misalignment between classification confidence and localization accuracyã€1ã€‘

2.1.1 NMSæ–¹æ³•å’Œä¸€äº›æ”¹è¿›

[parameter free]

  • NMSï¼šæ‰¾åˆ°æœ€å¤§åˆ†ç±»ç½®ä¿¡åº¦çš„æ¡†ï¼Œå¹¶æŠŠé‚»è¿‘çš„ä¸è¯¥æ¡†é‡åˆå¤§ä¸predefined overlapping thresholdå€¼çš„æ¡†è¿›è¡Œæ¶ˆé™¤ã€‚

[parameter-based methods]ï¼ˆéœ€è¦æ›´å¤šè®¡ç®—åŠ›ï¼‰

  • Learning-based Algorithmï¼šè®¡ç®—æ‰€æœ‰bboxçš„overlapçŸ©é˜µï¼Œä½¿ç”¨APèšç±»è¿›è¡Œé€‰æ‹©ã€‚

  • End-to-end networkï¼šä½¿ç”¨ç«¯åˆ°ç«¯ç½‘ç»œå­¦ä¹ detected bboxä¹‹é—´çš„å…³ç³»ã€‚

2.1.2 åˆ†æ

2.1.2.1 åˆ†å¸ƒå¯è§†åŒ–

â€‹åœ¨NMSæ­¥éª¤å‰ï¼Œclassification confidenceå’Œlocalization confidenceåœ¨æ‰€æœ‰bboxä¸­çš„åˆ†å¸ƒå¯è§†åŒ–å›¾å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼š

xåæ ‡è¡¨ç¤ºdetected boxå’Œground-truthä¹‹é—´çš„IoUï¼Œyåæ ‡è¡¨ç¤ºå…¶ç±»åˆ«ç½®ä¿¡åº¦ã€‚

â€‹é€šè¿‡åˆ†æPearson correlation coefficientï¼ˆçš®å°”é€Šç›¸å…³ç³»æ•°ï¼Œè¡¡é‡çº¿æ€§ç›¸å…³ç¨‹åº¦ï¼‰ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬å¯ä»¥è®¤ä¸ºlocalization accuracyå’Œåˆ†ç±»ç½®ä¿¡åº¦æ²¡æœ‰å¾ˆå¤§çš„ç›¸å…³æ€§ã€‚

â€‹ä¸Šè¿°æƒ…å†µäº§ç”Ÿçš„åŸå› ä¸ºï¼š

â€‹å¾ˆå¤šåŸºäºCNNçš„æ£€æµ‹å™¨åœ¨åŒºåˆ†å‰æ™¯å’ŒèƒŒæ™¯æ—¶ï¼Œå¦‚æœæ£€æµ‹åˆ°çš„boxdetbox_{det}boxdetâ€‹ä¸ground-truthä¹‹ä¸€çš„IoU > é˜ˆå€¼Î©train\Omega_{train}Î©trainâ€‹ï¼Œåˆ™è®¤ä¸ºæ˜¯æ­£ä¾‹ã€‚è¨€ä¸‹ä¹‹æ„å³ï¼Œå¦‚æœIoUå¤§ä¸ä¸€å®šé˜ˆå€¼çš„boxå°±å…¨éƒ¨å¼„è¿›æ¥çš„è¯ï¼Œä¼šé™ä½bboxå®šä½çš„å‡†ç¡®æ€§ã€‚

â€‹æ¯”å¦‚ä¸‹å›¾ä¸­åˆ†ç±»ç½®ä¿¡åº¦å¤§ä½†å®šä½ä¸å¤ªå‡†ç¡®çš„çº¢è‰²æ¡†ï¼š

2.1.2.2 NMS / IoU-Guided NMS / No-NMS

é—®é¢˜ï¼šä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆNMSå’ŒIoU-Guided NMSåœ¨0.5/0.6/0.7çš„æ—¶å€™äº§ç”Ÿçš„boxesæ¯”No-NMSçš„è¿˜å¤šï¼Ÿ

æ˜¯å¦æ˜¯å› ä¸ºåœ¨RPNä¸­åšçš„NMSï¼Œæœ¬èº«çš„anchor boxå°±å·²ç»è¶…å‡ºground-truthå¾ˆå¤šäº†ï¼Ÿ

é—®é¢˜ï¼šæ–‡ç« ä¸­çš„Repulsion Lossæ˜¯æŒ‡çš„ä»€ä¹ˆï¼Ÿ

2.2 Non-monotonic bounding box regressionã€2ã€‘

â€‹Cai, Z., Vasconcelos, N.: Cascade r-cnn: Delving into high quality object detection. arXiv preprint arXiv:1712.00726 (2017) ä¸­æå‡ºåº”ç”¨bbox regè¶…è¿‡ä¸¤æ¬¡å¹¶ä¸èƒ½å¸¦æ¥æ˜¾è‘—æå‡ï¼Œå…¶åŸå› æ˜¯å¤šæ­¥bbox regäº§ç”Ÿäº†distribution mismatchï¼Œå¯ä»¥é€šè¿‡é‡é‡‡æ ·ç­–ç•¥è§£å†³è¿™ä¸ªé—®é¢˜ã€‚

â€‹è¿­ä»£bbox regçš„æ€§èƒ½å¦‚ä¸‹å›¾ï¼š

3. IoU-Net

â€‹IoU predictorä»FPNæå–è§†è§‰ç‰¹å¾å¹¶ä¸”å¯¹æ¯ä¸ªbboxä¼°è®¡localization accuracyï¼ˆIoUï¼‰ã€‚

é—®é¢˜ï¼šclass-aware IoU predictorsæ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆæ„æ€ï¼Ÿ

+cls score //

3.1 IoU predictor

â€‹æœ¬æ–‡IoUé¢„æµ‹å™¨çš„è¾“å…¥ä¸æ˜¯ç”¨RPNäº§ç”Ÿçš„RoIsï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯å¯¹Ground Truthæ¡†éšæœºæ‰°åŠ¨ï¼Œå¾—åˆ°Jittered RoIsï¼Œè¿‡æ»¤æ‰ä¸GTçš„IoU<0.5çš„æ¡†ï¼Œå‰©ä¸‹çš„ä½œä¸ºè¾“å…¥ï¼Œç»è¿‡PrRoI Poolingç»™IoU predictorã€‚

3.2 IoU-guided NMS

â€‹æœ¬æ–‡é€šè¿‡IoU-guided NMSæ¥è§£å†³misalignment between classification confidence and localization accuracyé—®é¢˜ã€‚

S\mathcal{S}Sï¼šclassification confidence

I\mathcal{I}Iï¼šlocalization confidenceï¼ˆIoUï¼‰
